Introduction
About this book
This book is a quick guide to the world of Kubuntu. It's a great way to get familiar with what you will find in a pristine Kubuntu environment directly after installation. The Kubuntu &kdistro-version; Quick Guide is a visual tour of the desktop providing pictures, useful information and tips at every step of the tour.
As a quick guide, this book does not aim to be a comprehensive reference to everything you will learn about the Kubuntu environment. This book assumes that readers have used a computer and are familiar with using mouse and keyboard.
About Kubuntu
Kubuntu is a complete implementation of the Ubuntu operating system. Instead of installing the GNOME desktop, Kubuntu installs the K Desktop Environment (commonly known as KDE). Kubuntu aims to be to KDE what Ubuntu is to GNOME: a great integrated Linux distribution with all the great features of Ubuntu, but based on KDE. The Kubuntu team is part of the Ubuntu community and therefore adheres to the same ideals enshrined in the Ubuntu Manifesto: that software should be available free of charge, that software tools should be usable by people in their local language and despite any disabilities, and that people should have the freedom to qcustomize and alter their software in whatever way they see fit.
The Kubuntu team makes the following commitment to its users:
Kubuntu uses the solid base of Ubuntu Linux plus the latest from KDE. We are part of the Ubuntu community and use their infrastructure and support. Our mission is to be the best KDE-based Linux distribution available.
Kubuntu will always be free of charge, and there is no extra fee for the enterprise edition . We make our very best work available to everyone on the same free terms.
Kubuntu includes the very best translations and accessibility infrastructure that the free software community has to offer to make it usable by as many people as possible.
Kubuntu is entirely committed to the principles of free software and open source development. We encourage people to use free and open source software, improve it and pass it on.
Kubuntu includes more than 1,000 pieces of software, starting with Linux version 2.6 and KDE 3.4. Kubuntu covers every standard desktop application, from word processing and spreadsheet applications, to Internet access applications, web server software, email software, programming languages, tools and of course, a nice collection of games.

Getting started with Kubuntu
Using a new operating system can be intimidating. This Getting Started guide will help get you up to speed with Kubuntu.
Login
Whenever Kubuntu is started, you are required to provide your username and password in order to access your desktop. The first user account is created during setup of the Kubuntu installation. Since Kubuntu is a multiuser system, a single computer can be used by many people. Additionally, you may also select a different desktop environment or shutdown/restart your computer by using the Session Type and Menu buttons.
Kubuntu Login Screen
By default, you may not login with the root user. This is intentionally done for security reasons.
The first user account created during installation also serves as the default administrator of your computer. There will be times that you will be asked for your user password when attempting to configure Kubuntu settings. You can also create extra users for Kubuntu with the KUser application.
The Kubuntu Desktop
This is the Kubuntu desktop. Everything you need to do with your computer can be accessed from different parts of the desktop. Kubuntu makes a plethora of tools and applications available to you and if the stock installation is not enough, additional software can be installed on demand over the Internet.
The Kubuntu &kdistro-version; Desktop
Toolbar
The Toolbar contains a number of important components to make getting around within Kubuntu easy. Each of these sections are documented below and almost every one may be moved, re-sized, and changed in a number of ways.
The K Menu
The blue K Menu at the lower left corner of your desktop gives you easy, menu-driven access to the software installed on your machine. The K Menu is comprised of three separators:
Actions
All Applications
Most Used Applications
The last separator is only displayed after one or more applications have been started. Applications can be started by selecting an application category from the All Applications separator group and then selecting a program from the application category submenu. It is a good idea to get familiar with the K Menu. It is a tool that you will use often and it is helpful to know where applications are located.
Panel Shortcuts
Panel shortcuts are generally located to the immediate right of the K Menu. They are often shown as icons representing the actions or applications invoked when clicked. Move your mouse pointer over a shortcut icon to see a tooltip that describes the event or program. Customize the shortcut panel by right-clicking on a shortcut and using the menu options that allow you to move, remove, edit, and add entries.
Desktop Pager
The desktop pager is a square with a default of four numbered sections. Each section represents a virtual desktop. Windows can be moved between desktops by right-clicking the window title bar, selecting the To desktop and choosing a desktop from the submenu. You may switch to other desktops by clicking on one of the squares. Try moving this help window around and watch the pager, notice how a preview of the windows in each desktop is displayed. You may right-click the pager and select Configure Desktops if you'd like to rename each desktop or change the number of desktops.
Window List
The window list is located to the right of the Desktop Pager and occupies the most space on your Toolbar. Whenever you launch an application, a small square with the title of each window appears within the Window List. You may click on any of the entries to switch back and forth between windows or you may also use the Alt Tab and Shift Alt Tab key combinations to switch back and forth between windows. Note that you can right-click on an entry on the Window List to perform such operations as closing the window or moving it to a different desktop.
System Tray
The System Tray is located immediately to the right of the Window List and left of the Trash Bin. Various important applications will reside here such as laptop battery meters, sound controls, and messenger/chat clients such as Kopete. As with the Panel Shortcuts, you may right click on System Tray icons to perform various tasks with each.
Trash Bin
The Trash Bin holds all files that are pending deletion. This exists as a safety measure to prevent you from accidentally deleting files. You may view the contents of or empty the Trash Bin by clicking on the Trash Bin icon.
Clock
The Clock is usually on the far right side of the Toolbar. It is capable of displaying the current system time in a number of formats. Right-click on the clock and select the Properties to see the various things you may change about your clock.
Toolbar Slider Button
The Toolbar Slider Button is the small blue arrow that's in the absolute lower right corner of your desktop on the end of the Toolbar. Clicking this arrow makes your Toolbar slide off to the right and out of your way. This is useful for clearing up some space or to un-clutter your display. You may click the button again to return your Toolbar to its normal state.
Starting an Application
There are a number of ways to start an application in Kubuntu, but for the purposes of this quick guide, we will only focus on several of the most commonly used methods.
First and foremost, The K Menu allows you to browse and start applications. Clicking on The K Menu will present you with a list of application categories under the All Applications heading. Browse the application categories and click on a highlighted application to start it.
You will notice various icons on the Toolbar that represent the applications they will start if you click them. If you hover your mouse pointer over a Toolbar icon a description of the application it launches will be displayed. You may add your own links to applications that you use often to the Toolbar by right-clicking on The K Menu icon and highlighting Panel Menu Add to Panel Application and clicking on the application you want to add.
If you know the exact name of the application you'd like to run, you may right-click on your desktop and select the Run Command menu item. From here you may manually enter your desired command and further customize the execution of said program by using the Options button. The Run Command window is also available through the K Menu.
Closing an Application
Closing an application in Kubuntu is usually a straight-forward matter, however, it may be accomplished in several different ways depending on the situation and personal choice.
For most applications, clicking on File Quit in the application's Menu Bar (upper-left corner of the application window) will close the application.
Clicking on the X button in the upper-right corner, on the window's titlebar, will close the application.
Right-clicking on the window's titlebar and choosing Close will quit the application.
Right-clicking on the application in your Toolbar's window list and choosing Close will quit the application.
If you prefer keyboard shortcuts, you may close an application by pressing Alt F4 on your keyboard.
Be sure to save your work in an application, if necessary, before you close it!
Connecting to a Printer
Kubuntu features the impressive KDE Printing Manager, which sports a host of useful features. Click on the K Menu button in your Toolbar and choose Utilities Printing Manager to start the Printing Manager Control Module. You can add, or connect to, a printer using this module.
Printing Manager
To add a printer, click
Add Add Printer/Class... to launch the Add Printer Wizard, which will walk you through the process of adding a local printer or connecting to a printer on your network.
Printer Wizard
Follow the directions presented in the Wizard to add a local printer or connect to a printer on your network.
You may need to click the Administrator Mode button before making changes to your printer settings.
If you'd like to see an icon in your System Tray when there are pending print jobs, start KJobViewer, which you will find in K Menu Utilities Print Jobs (KJobViewer) . Clicking on the tray icon when it appears during printing will bring up a dialogue that will allow you to easily move, pause, and cancel print jobs. Note that the tray icon is only present while you are in the process of printing a document(s).
Connecting to the Internet
Connecting to the Internet is a breeze with Kubuntu! Whether you use a broadband Internet connection or a dial-up modem, Kubuntu's built-in utilities will have you connected in no time.
Configuring a broadband Internet connection
If you use a broadband Internet connection (cable, DSL, etc.), in many cases you will be connected right out-of-the-box. However, if you require additional configuration (i.e. proxies, static IP, etc.) click The K Menu icon in your Toolbar and choose Control Center. Once the Control Center starts, choose Internet & Network from the left panel to access the various Internet and networking related settings.
Modifying some of the settings in this module will require Administrator Mode. Click the Administrator Mode button and enter your password when necessary.
Network Settings - Control Center
Configuring a Dial-Up Connection
If you use a dial-up connection, Kubuntu has you covered as well. Launch the KPPP application by clicking The K Menu icon in your Toolbar and choosing Internet KPPP (Internet Dial-Up Tool) . KPPP is a dialer that handles the configuration needed to get you connected to your Internet Service Provider. It will automate dialing-in while letting you monitor the entire process.
KPPP (Internet Dial-Up Tool)
Click the Configure button to set up a new dial-up account.
Installing additional Applications

Adept is a graphical package management tool based on KDE and APTAdept enables you to install, upgrade and remove software packages in a user friendly way. You may launch Adept from K Menu System Adept Manager .
Adept
Software is organized into groups of packages in Kubuntu. To make things easier to find, each package is sorted under sections. You may browse the contents of each section by clicking on one of the entries in the left scroll menu. This will show all packages belonging to the selected section in the right scroll menu. If you'd like to cycle through some different ways to sort packages, select the drop-down menu in the upper left corner and choose one of the entries there.
Finding Packages
Find the application you are interested in installing either through the Section filter or by Finding the application by pressing Ctrl F . From the Find Packages menu, you may enter a search phrase or specify how your search is to be carried out. Results are displayed in the scroll box at the bottom of the dialog.
Installing Packages
Right-click the application name in the right-hand column and choose Install. Repeat this procedure for every application you wish to add to the system.
When you are finished, click the Commit changes to the system icon on the Kynaptic Toolbar, or press Ctrl C .
Upgrading Packages
In order to stay up to date with the latest security and bug fixes, it's important to update the software on your system periodically. You may do this by clicking the Refresh button (or by pressing Ctrl R ), then clicking the Upgrade all packages button on the toolbar (or Ctrl U ).
When you are finished, click the Commit changes to the system icon on the Kynaptic Toolbar, or press Ctrl C .
Removing Packages
Occasionally you may wish to remove software from your computer. This may be done by right-clicking on a software entry and selecting Remove. Ideally, a red 'X' will appear beside the application's name, indicating that the package is to be removed. However, sometimes you will find that another application depends on the software you're removing in order to function. In this case, another menu will appear showing you which applications will be removed in order to make sure things remain functional. In this case you may click Cancel to abort removing the specified packages. When you are happy with your changes, click the Commit button on the toolbar or press Ctrl C .
If you change your mind about un-installing a package before committing the changes, you may right-click on the package's name and select Unmark.
Logging Out from Kubuntu
There are several ways to log out of, or end, your Kubuntu session. Use one of these procedures if you wish to switch users, shutdown or reboot your system.
Right-click on an empty area of your Kubuntu Desktop and choose Log Out user... (where user represents your username).
Log Out Menu Item
You may also click on The K Menu icon in the Toolbar and choose Log Out....
The K Menu Log Out Item
Either of the log out methods described above will result in the End Session Screen.
End Session Screen
Choosing End Current Session will quit your Kubuntu session and return you to the login screen where you can switch users and start a new session, reboot or shutdown. Choosing Turn Off Computer will shutdown and power-off your system. Clicking on Restart Computer will reboot.

Find Files/Folders (KFind)
The Find Files tool is a useful method of searching for specific files on your computer, or for searching for files that match a pattern. An example of this could include searching for files of a particular type or with certain letters in the filename. You can load this utility by clicking on Find Files. This will launch KFind.
Find Files/Folders
For more information see the KFind manual.
Help
Help launches the KDE Help Center. You can search for various help documentation for Kubuntu in the Help Center. It includes a search utility and a tree-based navigation window to locate that help document you need in the least amount of time.
The KDE Help Center
For more information see the KHelpCenter manual.
Run Command
The Run Command utility manually lets you run an application or view certain documents by using command line instructions. You can choose the method of running an application with different options like running in a terminal window, as a different user, with a different priority, and with realtime scheduling. Use the Run Command only if you know what you are doing.
Kubuntu Run Command utility
Switch User
Kubuntu, being a multiuser operating system, allows you to switch between users and start new Kubuntu sessions on the fly without forcing the existing user to log out of the system.
Switch User
Lock Session
If you are leaving but do not want to turn off your Kubuntu system, it's a good idea to lock your current session to protect your system from unauthorized access. Select Lock Session from the K Menu to lock your system. When you get back, you can always unlock your system by giving your username and password.
Log Out
If you intend to finish your Kubuntu session or switch to another user, use the Log Out button to end your existing session. Once you select Log Out, you are given options to end current session, turn off the computer or restart your computer. You can also cancel the log out process by clicking Cancel.
The System Menu
The System menu gives easy access to system places.
Home Folder
The Home Folder is where all your files are located. Make sure you keep all your files in this location so that you can easily refer to them in the future. You can create new folders here to organize your data.
Home Folder
Storage Media
Storage Media lists your storage drives, partitions, and even external devices like USB flash storage. Depending on the file system of the storage media, you can add and remove files within Konqueror.
Storage Media
Remote Places
Remote Places shows your network shares and network places. If you are on a Windows network, you can explore your network by clicking on Samba Shares. This will list the available domains and workgroups in your network.
Remote Places
If you would like to add new network places, click the Add a Network Folder button and follow the wizard that appears. Network folders may use protocols such as Webdav, FTP, SMB, or SSH.
Settings
Settings is a convenient shortcut to Control Center inside Konqueror.
Kubuntu Settings
Trash
Trash is where files are kept pending deletion. They are moved here instead of being removed outright in order to prevent accidental deletion of important files. You may view the contents of your Trashcan to see what files are pending deletion.
Trash
